metadata.title: Traction, Mechanical (Cervical)
description: Traction is the application of tensile forces to the long axis of the spine.(1) Cervical traction is a conservative treatment for neck pain and symptoms associated with mechanical neck pathology such as disc herniation or muscle spasm. Traction may be applied mechanically or manually. Mechanical cervical traction generally makes use of a hydraulic or motorized pulley system with weights, as well as a harness or other device to attach to the patient’s head. Pneumatic traction units are also available. Manual traction is a manual therapy technique in which the therapist uses his/her hands to pull a patient’s head in a cephalad direction. This clinical review focuses on mechanical cervical traction
indications: Cervical traction is commonly used for treatment of neck pain.(2) Specific indications for its use have not been clearly established.(1) Expert consensus is that it is most appropriate for patients with neck and upper extremity symptoms and signs of neurologic compromise for whom centralization of symptoms is a treatment goal(1,2)
reimbursement: Reimbursement will depend on insurance coverage. Many plans consider cervical traction devices for home use to be medically necessary durable medical equipment (DME) to alleviate pain when certain criteria are met. Typical criteria include completion of a course of physical therapy that includes cervical traction Indications for procedure

indications for procedure: Indications for cervical traction for mechanical pain syndromes have not been clearly established(1)

Historically, it has been most commonly used for patients with signs and symptoms of radiculopathy(1) It is a preferred intervention for patients presenting with radiating upper extremity symptoms(1) indicated by: –provocation of upper extremity symptoms with foraminal compression –reduction of symptoms with manual traction –neurological involvement evidenced by sensory, motor, and reflex deficits
Mechanical cervical traction is frequently used to treat cervical disc herniation, cervical spondylosis, and cervical facet joint lesions

Proposed mechanisms for its effects include decreasing paraspinal muscle spasm, opening intervertebral foramina, increasing intervertebral disc space, improving vertebral alignment, and improving disc hydration(3) In a research study from South Korea, cervical disc herniation was shown to resolve during cervical traction(4)  –MRI during traction using a nonmagnetic traction device was used to evaluate the reducibility of cervical disc herniation –Out of 29 patients participating, disc herniation was completely resolved in 3 patients and partially reduced in 18 patients during intermittent cervical traction –21 patients had a substantial increase in the length of the cervical vertebral column during traction
Patients whose neck symptoms are reduced or relieved by manual traction may benefit from addition of mechanical traction to their treatment regimen(1)

contraindications: Acute cervical trauma, including whiplash-associated  disorders
Use of steroids or other medications that can weaken bone
Rheumatoid disorders affecting connective tissue, including rheumatoid arthritis and ankylosing spondylitis
Joint hypermobility/instability–Including positive results on Sharp-Purser  and/or alar ligament testing–Spondylolisthesis and instability withflexion and extension radiography
Application to areas where motion is contraindicated
Diseases and conditions resulting in increased joint laxity including but not limited to Marfan syndrome, Ehlers Danlossyndromes, Down syndrome
precautions: Being confined in a harness on a traction table in the supine position may be uncomfortable or distressing for patients withclaustrophobia or COPD–It is important for the patient to be able to relax to obtain the benefits of the procedure

Prior surgical stabilization or decompression–Application of cervical traction to patients with pathology in an area adjacent to prior anterior cervical discectomy andfusion has been reported in a case series(7)-Use of cervical traction postoperatively is not well documented and guidelines are not available-Loosening of cervical implants, cervical instability, and failure of implants are concerns. It is important to allowsufficient healing time prior to considering traction. Ligaments may take up to 12 months to heal and remodeling ofbone can take years. It is therefore necessary to get radiographic evidence of healing
Patients whose symptoms have increased or peripheralize with traction
Pregnancy, most concern in third trimester

Cardiovascular or cardiorespiratory problems(8)–Perturbations of the cardiovascular system during mechanical cervical traction have been reported–A decrease in systolic blood pressure (SBP), diastolic blood pressure (DBP), and rate pressure product (RPP) has beenreported following traction in the supine and sitting positions-RPP = SBPx heart rate(HR)–In a study conducted in Nigeria it was observed that 5 minutes post cervical traction, application subjects’ BP had notreturned to baseline levels. This suggests that vital signs should be monitored following treatment and that patients shouldnot be allowed to leave the treatment area until vital signs are stable(8)–Conversely, in a case series of 30 patients undergoing upper cervical traction, there was no change in blood flow in thevertebral artery during treatment(13)

mechanical or manual cervical traction m: Results from an RCT comparing cervical traction in sitting and in supine concluded that the supine position was superiorfor the treatment of cervical radiculopathy(14)–Based on a study in Pakistan of 40 patients with cervical radiculopathy–All patients received hot pack and TENS as well as traction in either supine or sitting. Traction parameters were 10% ofbody weight at 45-degree  cervical flexion angle, 5 sessions per week, 20 minutes per session–Outcome measure was Neck Disability Index
a traction table is commonly used for me: A fixed traction unit installed at one end produces the tensile force via a cable attached to a motor

An adjustable harness is usually used to secure the patient’s head to the cable–Harness designs include chin straps and occipital harnesses. Occipital harnesses are preferred to avoid forces beingapplied through the mandible or temporomandibular joint (TMJ). Occipital harnesses usually have a forehead strap tohold the patient’s head firmly in place
A patient-controlled  safety switch allows the patient to immediately release the traction if desired
Dosage parameters include magnitude of tensile force applied, duration of treatment, and intermittent cycle duration

Traction may be applied statically or intermittently. The majority of practitioners use intermittent traction, often using halfof the highest tension for the lower tension amount (e.g., 25 pounds alternated with 12.5 pounds)(1)
Typical amounts of tension used are between 10 and 25 pounds. Slightly larger values may be used if higher positions ofcervical flexion are used(1)

The angle of pull is adjusted to allow the desired amount of cervical flexion and lateral flexion(1)–Research has shown a decrease in pressure within the intervertebral foramen and increase in the dimensions of theintervertebral foramen with cervical flexion–Clinicians often treat with more cervical flexion in lower cervical spine levels (C6–C7)  and less cervical flexion forintermediate or higher cervical spine levels, although this technique has not been validated–Lateral flexion is sometimes added if symptoms are unilateral or asymmetric

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -When did symptoms begin? -Are symptoms increasing, decreasing, or unchanged? -Were symptoms associated with an injury or particular activity?

course of treatment.medical management: What treatment has patient received? How has the pain responded to any received treatment?
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? How effective are they? Opioids, NSAIDs, muscle relaxants (e.g., cyclobenzaprine [Flexeril]), antidepressants (e.g., venlafaxine [Effexor]), and analgesics may be prescribed
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Usual tests for conditions treated with this procedure are the following:
X-ray  to assess for a decrease in disc height, osteophytes, and fracture
MRI to detect a herniated disc pathology
EMG to distinguish between cervical radiculopathy and peripheral nerve entrapment
Possible Doppler tests if vertebral artery insufficiency is suspected
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful. Specifically inquire about prior use of cervical traction, both manual and mechanical

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: What activities or positions aggravate or ease symptoms?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms -C2  posterior occipital headaches, temporal pain -C3  occipital headache, retro-orbital  or retroauricular pain -C4  base of neck, pain in the trapezius muscle -C5  pain in the lateral arm -C6  radial forearm pain, thumb and index finger pain -C7  pain in the 2nd finger -C8  pain in the 3rd and 4th fingers -T1  ulnar forearm pain
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. What position does the patient sleep in? What type of pillow does the patient use?Document any use of supplemental oxygen or the need for ventilation
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Inquire about previous neck, upper back, or shoulder injury or dysfunction
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, sleep apnea, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing, such as migraines, dizziness, and tinnitusAny history of COPD or respiratory compromise?

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: What type of work does the patient do? How is the work environment set up? What home activities and leisure activities does the patient participate in? Risk factors for neck pain include poor workstation ergonomics, an occupation/hobby involving repetitive neck or upper extremity motion or upper extremity elevation, and poor posture
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: (include limitations with self-care, home management, work, community leisure)
social and occupational history.living environment: stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess need for cervical collar (day or night use) to provide temporary support and symptomatic relief. Assess need for cervical pillow to facilitate more appropriate cervical head positioning during sleep
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess balance using a standardized test such as the Berg Balance Scale as indicated
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Increases in SBP,DBP, and HR variability were reported during cervical traction using large forces (> 30% of body
weight) in a study conducted in Taiwan.(3) These changes were not observed when smaller forces (1020%  of body weight) were used
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess distal pulses and capillary fillingAssess myotomes, dermatomes, and peripheral nerve distributions to differentiate between peripheral neuropathy and cervical radiculopathy. Reflex testing of the upper and lower extremities can help to rule in/out cervical myelopathy and radiculopathy. Evaluation of upper limb neurodynamic mobility can help discern between a cervical radiculopathy and a peripheral nerve entrapment. (See Clinical Review…Radiculopathy, Cervical ;T708549 for more information)Does the patient use compensatory motions during functional movement? Evaluation of workplace/home/hobby area to determine cause of repetitive stress may be indicated. Look for workstation design that may contribute to faulty cervical posture
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess functional mobility, as indicated, using standardized tool such as FIMAssess joint mobility of cervical and thoracic spine
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess pain-free  neck muscle strength using manual muscle testing (maximum strength may be limited by pain). Also assess strength of upper extremity and scapulothoracic movements
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess positioning of head, neck, and shoulders in static sitting and standing as well as during functional activities. Assess for tightened muscles that may contribute to poor neck posture (forward head, decreased cervical lordosis, increased thoracic kyphosis, forward shoulders)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess cervical ROM (muscle shortening and/or pain may restrict mobility). Also assess for provocation of radicular pain or dizziness with active cervical ROM. Goniometric assessment is appropriate in cases with clinically significant loss. Screen the upper extremities and temporomandibular joint, as indicated
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess deep tendon reflexes for hyporeflexia, which may indicate nerve root involvement brachioradialis (C5, C6), triceps (C6, C7, C8). Assess lower extremity deep tendon reflexes for hyperreflexia, which maypatellar reflex (L2, L3, L4), Achilles reflex (S1, S2) as indicatedAssess ADLs as indicated
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess temperature, light touch, and deep pressure sensation in dermatomes C1–7.  Decreased or loss of sensation is indicative of cervical radiculopathy
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Neck Disability Index (NDI) – an instrument for measuring self-rated  disability due to neck pain -10 items are scored from 0 to 5 -High level of reliability and validity has been reported(5) -The NDI in conjunction with the numeric pain rating scale has been reported to provide a more comprehensive assessment of the patient with cervical radiculopathy, allowing the clinician to make better judgments about the effects of cervical traction –Shoulder Abduction Test(2) – tests for cervical radiculopathy -While sitting, the patient is instructed to place the hand of the affected arm on his or her head -Alleviation of symptoms with this maneuver is a positive test result  –Neck distraction test(2) -Patient lies supine with neck comfortably positioned -Examiner securely grasps the patient’s head under the occiput and chin and gradually applies an axial traction force up to approximately 30 lbs -A reduction or elimination of symptoms is a positive result –Upper limb tension tests – sequence of movements with patient in supine that reproduces patient’s pain(2)Shoulder girdle depression; shoulder abduction; forearm supination, wrist and finger extension; shoulder external rotation; elbow extension; contralateral then ipsilateral side bendingShoulder girdle depression; elbow extension; lateral rotation of the whole arm; wrist, finger, and thumb extensionShoulder girdle depression; elbow extension; medial rotation of the whole arm; wrist, finger, and thumb flexionWrist and finger extension; forearm pronation; elbow flexion; shoulder girdle depression; shoulder lateral rotation; shoulder abduction -Positive result is unilateral and indicative of cervical radiculopathy –Spurling (maneuver) test may be used to evaluate patients for cervical radiculopathy -Symptoms are elicited by extending, rotating, and laterally flexing the patient’s neck toward the symptomatic side. The examiner then applies axial pressure on the spine. Pressure applied on top of the head may intensify symptoms -The Spurling test has low sensitivity but high specificity. Therefore, it is not useful as a screening tool to rule out cervical radiculopathy, but it does help confirm the diagnosis -The Spurling test is also known as the quadrant test
relevant tests and measures.oral structure and oral motor function: Assess for signs of upper motor neuron (UMN) lesions (e.g., hypertonicity, hyperreflexia, clonus, unsteady gait, positive Babinski sign) and lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions (weakness, muscle wasting, hyporeflexia or areflexia, hypotonicity). Cervical compressive myelopathy may present with UMN signs below the level of the lesion and LMN signs at the level of the lesion. Assess upper and lower extremities where myelopathy is suspected. (See ClinicalT708511 for more information)

other: The therapist should discuss with the patient the sensations to be expected during traction. The patient should be told to notify the therapist immediately if pain increases(1)
Patients should be provided a safety switch to immediately release the traction, or a call bell to call for assistance
The therapist should observe the traction being applied and the patient’s response for several minutes when the session begins before leaving the patient unsupervised

The traction dosage (amount of tension, duration, and cycle duration with intermittent traction) should be conservative initially and gradually increased based on patient’s response.(1) The amount of tension applied should not cause or increase symptoms

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Neck pain with signs and symptoms of radiculopathies, including radiating upper extremity symptoms; cervical stiffness related to muscle spasm or facet joint pathology(1) A clinical prediction rule to identify patients with neck pain likely to improve with cervical traction was developed in a 2009 study performed in the United States(2) –A prospective cohort of patients with neck pain referred to physical therapy was studied –Patients completed 6 sessions of intermittent cervical traction and exercise twice weekly for 3 weeks. Outcome was determined by patients’ perceived recovery. History and examination items of patients who had a successful outcome were analyzed –Five variables were identified: patient-reported peripheralization with lower cervical spine mobility testing; positive shoulder abduction test; age ≥ 55; positive upper limb tension test; positive neck distraction test –Pretest probability of success with cervical traction was 44%. If a patient had 4 out of 5 criteria, the post-test probability of success was 94.8%. Having 3 out of 5 criteria still resulted in a post-test  success rate of 79.2% A clinical prediction rule to identify patients with neck pain likely to benefit from home-based  mechanical cervical traction (HMCT) was developed in a 2011 study performed in Singapore(6) –A prospective cohort of patients referred to physical therapy for neck pain was studied –A total of 103 patients participated in the study; 47 had a positive response to HMCT (45.6%) –Four variables were identified: Fear-Avoidance  Beliefs Work Subscale score < 13, pre-intervention  pain intensity ≥7/10, positive neck distraction test, and pain below the shoulder –When at least 3 of these 4 criteria were met, the intervention’s success rate was over 80%
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Physiatrist for trigger point injections, neurologist for persistent radicular or neurological symptoms, acupuncturist for alternative pain management, occupational therapist for ADL training, chiropractor for spinal adjustment, as indicated
other considerations: Results from a survey of PTs in the United States indicated that the use of cervical traction by PTs is consistent with the proposed criteria for identification of patients who would benefit(15) –Response rate was 25.5%, with 93.1% of these respondents indicating they would use traction for patients with nerve root compression –Traction was most often used as a supplement to other modalities (e.g., exercise, postural education, joint mobilization) –PTs with a specialty certificate in orthopedics were more likely to choose to use traction when compared to PTs without a specialty certificate

The author of a study conducted in Japan used ultrasonography to measure muscle thickness changes with different mechanical traction forces as an objective measure of the effects of traction(11) –The thicknesses of the trapezius and splenius capitis muscles before traction and during traction at three different forces were measured –At 5 kg and 8 kg, thickness of the trapezius muscle hardly changed during traction. At 11 kg, significant differences in muscle thickness occurred, indicating that extension of the trapezius required greater traction force –In the splenius capitis muscle, muscle thickness did not change at 5 kg, but significant differences were found at 8 kg and 11 kg –The splenius capitis muscle is more aligned in the direction of the traction; the differences in muscle direction between these two muscles may account for the different results at 8 kg
treatment summary: Authors of a 2018 systematic review and meta-analysis  of 5 RCTs concluded that adding traction to a physical therapy program for patients with cervical radiculopathy had significant short-  and intermediate-term  benefits for pain and intermediate-term  benefits for disability(16) –Manual therapy was found to have significant effects in the short-term
Results from a 2018 meta-analysis  of seven RCTs suggest that intermittent cervical traction may result in temporarily decreased pain(12)

The Orthopaedic Section of the American Physical Therapy Association (APTA) 2017 guidelines for neck pain include the following recommendations for the use of mechanical cervical traction in conjunction with other modalities, exercise, and mobilizations:(17) –Chronic neck pain with mobility deficits – level B evidence –Chronic neck pain with radiating pain – level B evidence

Studies of intermittent cervical traction for cervical radiculopathy suggest that it is beneficial for reducing pain and improving function as an adjunct to other treatment(1) –In a 2014 RCT conducted in the United States involving 86 patients with signs of cervical radiculopathy, the addition of intermittent mechanical traction to exercise resulted in lower disability and pain scores(9) -In this study, the benefits of traction were noted at longer-term  follow-ups  but there was no placebo intervention, so it is hard to rule out the placebo effect -The above study included manual therapy as a component of standard treatment –Results of an RCT comparing manual and mechanical cervical traction in which all patients received mobilization and exercise therapy indicated that mechanical traction was more effective than manual therapy in managing the pain and disability of cervical radiculopathy(18) -Based in Pakistan, this study involved 36 patients -Patients received treatment 3x/week for 6 weeks -Outcome measures were NDI and the numeric pain rating scale

There is no consensus about whether mechanical cervical traction is beneficial for nonspecific neck pain without radiculopathy  –Results of an RCT conducted in India indicate that intermittent mechanical cervical traction provides additional benefits when included along with conventional physiotherapy treatment for mechanical neck pain(10) -Forty patients with mechanical neck pain, defined as pain aggravated by movement, relieved by rest, and not associated with underlying pathology, were randomly assigned to receive conventional physical therapy only or mechanical traction in addition to conventional physical therapy -Conventional physical therapy consisted of ultrasound and isometric neck exercises -Intermittent manual traction was prescribed for 20 minutes with 40-second  hold time, 10-second rest in supine in 15-degree  neck flexion. Pull of traction was 1/10th patient’s body weight -Outcome measures included the NDI, cervical goniometry, and the numeric pain rating scale -Both groups showed improvements in cervical mobility, pain reduction, and disability perception. The group receiving mechanical cervical traction had greater reductions in NDI and numeric pain rating scale scores and greater improvement in cervical mobility; these improvements were statistically significant

The author of a case series on the use of cervical traction for herniated nucleus pulposus after anterior cervical discectomy and fusion reported significant reduction in symptoms, including at least partial resolution of myopathy/radicular symptoms of numbness and weakness(7) –For patients with well-healed  anterior cervical discectomy and fusion surgeries presenting with coexisting pathologies such as disc herniation, mechanical cervical traction may be beneficial –Since correction of disc protrusion by traction alone may not be sufficient for long-term  relief of symptoms, patients also received posture education and correction and cervical stabilization and stretching exercises ›See Description, Indications of device/equipment , and Guidelines for use of device/equipment , above . maintenance or prevention: A home exercise program to maintain or improve impairments should be prescribed
A home traction device may be beneficial for patients who respond favorably to in-clinic  traction
Education on proper ergonomics and body mechanics and how to modify tasks that increase the pain
